Judul: EFFECTS OF BIOMASS TYPES AND COAL RANKS ON CHARACTERISTICS OF HYBRID COAL PRODUCED IN A SEMI-PILOT SCALE CO-TORREFACTION REACTOR
Abstrak:
Coal is an inexpensive and abundant source of energy in Indonesia, but its utilisation is
limited because Indonesia’s reserves are dominated by low-rank coal. Biomass residue is
also abundant and can be used as an alternative source of energy. Coal and biomass can
be utilised together through co-torrefaction to produce hybrid coal. There have been
various studies carried out in a laboratory scale, however, insufficient studies are carried
out in a semi-pilot scale. The purpose of this research is to upgrade the quality of lowrank
coal by variation of biomass and coal ranks and characterizing the hybrid coal
produced by calorific value, proximate and ultimate analysis, and also to create an
environmentally friendly fuel by determining the potential non-neutral carbon dioxide
emission reduction by hybrid coal in a semi-pilot scale.
The study was done with the variation of biomass types and coal ranks which was
conducted in a semi-double chamber reactor under atmospheric conditions using lowrank
coal of lignite and sub-bituminous along with biomass sawdust of pinewood and
rubberwood. The biomass and coal were ground and sieved to size (50-100 mesh) and
(30-100 mesh), respectively. The biomass composition in the mixture of coal and biomass
is 30%-weight. The heat was supplied by multiple feedings of biomass as fuel in the form
of sawdust through the combustion process. The amount of biomass combusted was 1.5
kg with 1:3 feed to fuel ratio.
The experimental finding shows that hybrid coal mass yield is in the range of 59.23-
62.70%. There is an increase in the fixed carbon content of hybrid coal from 12.95-
38.04%-w to 50.24-60.13%-w, a decrease in water content, a decrease in the volatile
matter, and a decrease in the value of O/C and H/C ratio. This causes an increase in the
calorific value of 14.45–38.88% and produces hybrid coal with a calorific value of 5916-
6348 cal/g. Energy yield is in the range of 69.85– 81.63% with the capability of CO2
emission reduction of 27.47- 32.66%. Lignite coal and rubberwood sawdust produce
hybrid coal with the highest reduction in non-neutral CO2 emissions.
